This comment references Sections 4.1.2.1, 4.1.2.2, and 4.1.2.3 of the Endangered Species Act Compensatory Mitigation Policy issued December 27, 2016.

These comments support the idea of 1) modifying the "mitigation sequence" (i.e., avoid, then minimize, then compensate) to allow compensatory mitigation to be considered earlier in the sequence when conditions warrant, and 2) including compensatory mitigation as reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) in the consideration of jeopardy and adverse modification determinations. 

There are many situations where avoiding and minimizing a proposed impact is unsustainable due to factors that cannot be controlled by the applicant or the regulatory agencies. The impacted site may be a remnant of past conditions or on an irreversible trend toward adverse change. Even permanent protection of the site may not produce beneficial results because of these adverse conditions or trends.

The concept of avoiding and minimizing impacts before considering compensatory mitigation is valid in a stable landscape where the impacts are relatively infrequent. In rapidly changing landscapes from urbanization, invasive species effects, intense resource extraction, intense agriculture, or climate change, however, it would be prudent to mentally project what the future landscape will offer the resource under consideration and then consider whether the resource is likely to be sustained if the impacts are avoided and minimized. There are many situations where advance mitigation under a strict regulatory framework, such as conservation or mitigation banking, will provide a higher probability of future sustainability than would avoidance and minimization.

These comments support the current language in the sections cited above and are intended to encourage the Service to fully implement a broader view of the mitigation sequence in light of likely future landscape scenarios, especially where conservation and mitigation banks have been established which offer a higher probability of sustaining the resource.
